title: provider: Local OCR backend
description:
Make the OCR backend pluggable so quarry can run without AWS credentials.

## Motivation
- Eliminates AWS dependency and per-page cost ($1.50/1000 pages)
- Enables offline use
- Simpler setup (no IAM, S3 bucket, or credentials needed)

## Approach
- Define an OcrBackend protocol with two operations: sync single-page OCR and async multi-page OCR
- Implement TextractBackend (existing code in ocr_client.py)
- Implement LocalBackend wrapping a local engine (PaddleOCR, EasyOCR, or Tesseract)
- Add OCR_BACKEND setting (default: "textract", alternative: "local")
- Pipeline calls backend through protocol, no other changes needed

## Candidates
- PaddleOCR: best accuracy, ~100MB models, CPU or GPU
- EasyOCR: good accuracy, PyTorch-based, ~200MB models
- Tesseract: simplest install, weakest accuracy on noisy/skewed scans

## Open Questions
- Which local engine? PaddleOCR has best benchmarks but adds PaddlePaddle dependency
- Should local be an optional extra (quarry-mcp[local])?
- Acceptable accuracy threshold for handwritten/skewed documents?

title: tool: Hybrid document-level search
description:
Add document-level search combining sparse (keyword) and dense (vector) retrieval to support exhaustive queries like 'how much did I spend on maintenance' where top-N chunk similarity is the wrong tool.

## Problem

Current search returns top-N chunks by vector similarity. Works for conceptual queries but fails for exhaustive queries that need ALL matching documents regardless of similarity rank. Document names are unreliable (e.g. scan.pdf, IMG_5349.jpg) so metadata filtering by name is insufficient.

## Design

### Document metadata table

At ingestion time, after chunking and embedding, generate and store per-document:
- Document-level embedding: np.mean(chunk_vectors, axis=0) — already computed, just store the mean
- Keywords: TF-IDF or statistical extraction from page text — zero additional API cost
- Store in a separate document_metadata table in LanceDB

### New MCP tool: find_documents

Hybrid search against the document metadata table:
- Dense: vector similarity against document-level embedding
- Sparse: keyword/BM25 matching against extracted terms
- LanceDB supports both natively (full-text search index + vector index)
- Returns document-level results (name, collection, pages, keywords) not chunks
- Small responses — document list only, no chunk text

### Retrieval flow for exhaustive queries

1. find_documents(collection='hallberg-rassy', query='invoice') → complete document list (small response)
2. get_page(doc, page) for each document → extract specific data
3. LLM aggregates the answers

### Retrieval flow for conceptual queries

search_documents (existing) — unchanged, top-N chunk similarity

## Cost

Zero additional API calls. Keywords extracted from existing text. Document embedding is mean of existing chunk vectors. Both computed at end of _chunk_embed_store.

title: tool: Optimize MCP response sizes
description:
Large MCP responses (~12.5k tokens) observed filling context quickly.

## Root cause

Exhaustive queries forced through top-N chunk search — addressed by ocr-4xq (hybrid document-level search).

## Residual optimization for search_documents

Even for conceptual queries, chunk-level search responses are larger than necessary:
- Truncate text field in results (e.g. 200 chars with ellipsis) — callers can use get_page for full text
- Drop chunk_index from results (rarely useful to callers)
- Consider default limit=5 instead of 10
- Consider a brief=true flag for compact responses

These are independent of ocr-4xq and worth doing regardless.

title: pipeline: PII detection and redaction
description:
Prevent PII from reaching LLM context windows via ingestion-time detection and retrieval-time redaction. Secure by default (on by default, opt-out).

## Threat Model

Users unknowingly send PII to LLMs through MCP responses. quarry stores invoices, contracts, and personal documents containing names, addresses, emails, phone numbers, and financial account numbers.

## Design

### Ingestion-time detection
- After chunking, run Microsoft Presidio analyzer on each chunk's text
- Store detected PII spans as metadata: entity type, start offset, end offset
- Store as JSON column (pii_spans) on each chunk row in LanceDB
- Also detect on page_raw_text separately (different offsets than chunk text)
- Embeddings computed on full unredacted text — preserves search quality

### Retrieval-time redaction
- Before returning MCP responses, apply stored spans to replace PII with placeholders
- Placeholder style: [PERSON], [EMAIL], [PHONE], [ADDRESS], etc. (Presidio standard)
- Applies to both search_documents results and get_page responses
- Toggle: pii_redaction setting in Settings, True by default

### Audit tool
- New MCP tool: find documents/chunks containing specific PII entity types
- Query stored pii_spans metadata across all chunks
- Example: 'which documents contain PHONE_NUMBER entities'

## Schema Addition

New column on chunks table:
  pii_spans: utf8 (JSON string)
  pii_spans_raw: utf8 (JSON string, for page_raw_text)

Example value:
  [{"type": "PERSON", "start": 42, "end": 55}, {"type": "EMAIL", "start": 120, "end": 148}]

## Dependencies

- Microsoft Presidio as optional dependency: quarry[pii] extra
- Presidio wraps spaCy + regex recognizers, runs locally, no API cost
- PII entity types: PERSON, EMAIL_ADDRESS, PHONE_NUMBER, LOCATION/ADDRESS, CREDIT_CARD, US_SSN, IBAN, and others from Presidio defaults

## Configuration

- pii_redaction: bool = True (secure by default)
- pii_entity_types: list of entity types to detect (default: all Presidio defaults)
- Per-collection config deferred

## Commits (rough)

1. Add Presidio as optional dependency, pii_redaction setting
2. Add pii_spans/pii_spans_raw columns to LanceDB schema
3. PII detection module wrapping Presidio analyzer
4. Integrate detection into _chunk_embed_store pipeline
5. Retrieval-time redaction in search and get_page MCP responses
6. Audit MCP tool: query PII spans across chunks
7. Tests for detection, redaction, and audit

title: infra: Add rename/move operation to database layer
description:
When a file is renamed or moved, the stored document_name and document_path in LanceDB become stale. Currently sync treats this as delete + re-ingest, wasting OCR and embedding compute.

## Database layer

Add rename_document() to database.py that updates document_name and document_path columns via table.update() with a WHERE filter. No re-embedding or re-chunking needed.

## Sync integration

In compute_sync_plan(), after building to_delete and to_ingest lists, cross-reference them: if a deletion candidate and an ingestion candidate share the same size+mtime, treat it as a rename instead of delete+ingest. mv preserves both attributes on the same filesystem.

SyncPlan gains a to_rename list of (old_record, new_path) tuples. sync_collection handles renames via rename_document() + registry update.

Ambiguous case (multiple files with identical size+mtime): fall back to delete+ingest.

## Three layers to update

1. LanceDB — document_name and document_path columns (rename_document)
2. SQLite registry — files table row: update path, document_name
3. Sync engine — rename detection in compute_sync_plan, rename execution in sync_collection
close_reason: Not pursuing rename support — delete+re-ingest is acceptable. Local OCR (ocr-1ke) reduces the cost of re-ingestion, making renames a non-issue.
